Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation of US-based researchers in the conference "Dynamics, Geometry, and Number Theory," held at the Institut Henri Poincare in Paris from June 13 through June 17, 2016. The theory of dynamical systems is a major mathematical discipline closely intertwined with most of the main areas of mathematics. Originating in the work of Poincare, Birkhoff, and von Neumann in the beginning of the twentieth century, it continued to evolve throughout the century, branching out in many directions. In recent decades there have been many spectacular advances in the applications of dynamics to geometry and number theory. The goal of the conference is to bring together an excellent group of researchers from around the world to discuss new research results and explore new ideas.

The conference will cover recent progress and developments of the theory of dynamical systems and its geometric and number-theoretic applications. In recent years there have been spectacular advances in the area, highlighting various connections between dynamics, rigidity, Diophantine approximation, combinatorics, and many other areas of mathematics. The organizers will take the opportunity to encourage more young researchers and junior faculties to work on dynamical systems and related research topics.

For more details, see the conference web page: www.math.u-psud.fr/~paulin/Margulis2016.html

POR.DRECONTENT:
The conference "Dynamics, Geometry and Number theory" held in Institut Henri Poincare in June 13-17 in 2016 was a great success.  Its organizing committee consisted of Breuilard, Karlsson, Kleinbock, Oh (the PI) and Paulin.

There were twenty one lectures by

Abels  on “The topological generating rank of Lie groups”,

Anatharaman on “Quantum ergodicity on large graphs”, Benoist on “Harmonic quasiisometries”,

Beresnevich on “Quantitative non-divergence in Diophantine approximation on manifolds”,

Burger on “Maximal representations, non Archimedean Siegel spaces, and buildings”,

Einsiedler on “Measure rigidity for diagonal actions on quotients of SL(3,R)xSL(3,R)”,

Filip on  “Teichmüller dynamics and Hodge theory”,

Eskin on  “Polygonal Billiards and Dynamics on Moduli Spaces”,

Furstenberg on “Are no algebraic numbers well-approximable ?”,

Goldman on “Dynamical systems arising from moduli of geometric structures”,

Katok on “Entropy and Lyapunov exponents : rigidity vs. flexibility”,

Labourie on “Surface groups in uniform lattices of complex simple groups”,

Lindenstrauss on “Diagonal actions in positive characteristic”,

Lubotzky on “Ramanujan complexes and topological expanders”,

Mohammadi on “Effective equidistribution of certain adelic periods”,

Pansu on “Large scale conformal maps”,

Salehi Golsefidy on “Super-approximation and its applications”,

Wienhard on “On rigidity and flexibility of (some) discrete subgroups of Lie groups”,

Wilkinson on “Partial hyperbolicity, exponents, and superrigidity” and

Ziegler  on “Concatenating cubic structures and patterns in primes”, and

Margulis “Mathematical and autobiographical recollections”.

The talks covered  broad range of  topics on Dynamics, Geometry, and Number theory as in the title with emphasis on interactions and  showcased Gregory Margulis' pioneering mathematical achievements. 

More than 200 people registered for the conference from the worldwide community, at all stages of their research careers. It attracted significant number of young participants such as graduate students and recent ph.D's.  The NSF grant was used to support the travels of graduate students, postdocs, mathematicians in early career  based at the US institutions with no other NSF supports.
